body:
Comment 7 by **skinner.david**: 
I really do not blame you for not wanting to install all of the
dependencies for qml to test this one case.

I really do not think it is possible, well I should say practical, to
provide a completely stand alone case other that what is presented, at
least for me as the problem is that there is a runtime seg fault on startup
with incompatible binary C libraries and I do not know or understand why
the libraries are not compatible. The true nature of my complaint is that
it took me several days with GDB (well it was the first time for me to use
it) to discover that the runtime seg fault on startup was in fact the
result of incompatible binary C libraries. I was rather hoping that that
you could:

   - Give a link warning that I am trying to use incompatible binary C
   libraries
   - Or give an informative runtime error that lets me know that I may
have incompatible
   binary C libraries that are unable to init.

Please understand that from my initial perspective, the runtime seg fault
on startup was caused by:
    go get -u
I think the only reason I had this problem in the first place is that I
would rather use other peoples code than write my own so I import a lot of
packages and only write what I have to. I always felt that to be a good
programmer, you had to be so lazy that you were willing to work all day to
automate a one hour job. At any rate, Go makes it easy to import and the
number of packages is increasing, this particular incident is fixed, the
current versions of these two libraries are now compatible. I am thinking
that it is more probable than not that it will happen again, eventually. I
suppose I like for my error messages to tell me what I need to do to fix
the problem I have created, I am not used to having problems that I did not
create and it really confused me.

I am sorry I cannot help.
